content: How can I help you today?

I guess I'm here because my wife kept insisting. Things have been tough at home, and honestly, I don't see how talking will fix it. Our son has been really struggling, and it's affecting everything—our marriage, work, even my relationship with my daughter. I just feel stuck and don't know where to start.

Thank you for sharing that—things sound really overwhelming right now. It’s understandable to feel stuck with so much going on. Your wife encouraging you to come here shows she cares, and taking this step could be a way to explore what’s happening. What’s been the toughest part for you lately?

I think the hardest part is feeling like I don't have any control over what's happening. My son’s behavior is so unpredictable, and I don’t know how to help him. It’s causing so much tension at home, and I’m scared it’s tearing my family apart. I just feel like I’m failing everyone.

It sounds like you're carrying a lot of worry and responsibility, and feeling powerless when things spiral out of control. You're deeply invested in your family and want to help them, but it’s hard when you’re unsure of what to do. What would feeling more in control look like for you right now?

I think feeling more in control would mean knowing what to do to help my son, and seeing some kind of progress with him. It’s like if I knew we were heading in the right direction, it would give me some hope. Right now, it just feels like everything is falling apart, and I don’t even know where to begin.

It sounds like having a clear sense of direction—some way forward with your son—might ease the weight you’re feeling and give you hope for your family. That sense of progress seems really important to you. What steps have you tried so far, or what has felt helpful, even in small ways?

We’ve tried talking to him, setting rules, being patient, even taking things away when he acts out, but nothing seems to stick. It’s like he’s just so angry all the time, and I don’t know how to reach him anymore. Honestly, it just feels like we’re failing as parents, and that’s such a hard thing to admit.

It sounds like you and your wife have put so much effort into trying to support your son, even when it feels like nothing is working. That shows a lot of dedication and love as parents, even during such a tough time. It must be painful to feel disconnected from him despite all you’ve tried. What do you think might be behind his anger or what he’s experiencing?

I really don’t know for sure. I’ve thought about it a lot, but he hasn’t opened up to us about what’s upsetting him. I wonder if it’s something at school or with friends, but I’m just not sure. I feel like I’m missing something obvious, and that makes it even harder.

It’s clear you’ve been searching for answers and care deeply about understanding what’s going on with him. Not knowing and feeling like you might be missing something sounds really frustrating. If he were to open up and share more, what do you think would help create that safe space for him to talk?

Maybe if I could just stay calm and patient, even when he lashes out, it would help. It’s hard, though, because I feel like I’m walking on eggshells all the time. Maybe he just doesn’t trust me right now, and I don’t know how to fix that.

You're really reflecting on ways to be patient and calm, even in such difficult moments, which shows how much you care about his feelings and your relationship with him. Walking on eggshells all the time must be very draining, and it sounds like rebuilding trust feels like an important goal for you. What do you think might help strengthen that connection, even in small ways?

Maybe just spending time with him without any pressure or expectation, you know? Like doing something he enjoys and just letting him know I’m there for him, no matter what. It’s hard because I feel like he’s always pushing me away, but maybe I need to stop taking it personally.

That’s a thoughtful approach—focusing on shared time without pressure and showing him that your support is unconditional. It sounds like you really want to meet him where he’s at, even though his actions feel personal at times. What activities do you think he might enjoy or feel comfortable with?

He really loves video games, and sometimes he’ll get super into explaining them to me. Maybe I could try sitting down and playing with him, even though I have no idea what I’m doing. It might help him feel like I care about what he loves, you know?

That sounds like a great idea—engaging with him through something he enjoys could help open the door to connection. Even if you’re not familiar with video games, just showing interest in what excites him might mean a lot. How do you feel about spending this kind of time with him, knowing it might take some patience and persistence to build that bond?

I think it might feel a bit awkward at first, but it’s worth trying if it means connecting with him. I just hope he doesn’t see it as me forcing myself into his space, you know? But I guess I’ll only know if I try.

It’s courageous that you’re willing to step into something unfamiliar, even if it feels awkward at first, because you care about connecting with him. Trying is a powerful action, and it shows how committed you are to making that bond stronger. Is there anything that you’d like to focus on for yourself as you take these steps to help your family?

I honestly haven't thought much about myself in all of this. It's been so focused on my son and trying to keep the family together. But maybe I need to figure out how to take care of myself too, otherwise, I don’t know how much more I can give.

It's insightful to recognize that taking care of yourself is an important part of being able to support your family. You’ve been putting so much energy into everyone else, and it’s okay to acknowledge your own needs. What kind of self-care or support would help you feel a little more grounded right now?
